titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 22:00

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection
did.abstract: The Miscellaneous Personal Papers record group is an open collection consisting of the correspondence, diaries, writings and/or other papers and memorabilia of various individuals. This collection contains papers of individuals who were Yale faculty members, alumni/ae, clergy, ecumenical workers, or missionaries in areas other than China.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: See the alphabetical listing for biographical information about the individuals included in this record group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, diaries, writings and/or other papers and memorabilia of various individuals, including former Yale faculty members, clergymen and missionaries to areas other than China. The papers of these men and women have been placed in the Miscellaneous Personal Papers record group because the quantity or substance of the material did not warrant a separate record group.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection (RG 30), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

Allison, Walter and Grace

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Walter Leslie Allison and Grace Fleck Allison served in North India from 1920 to 1954 as educational and evangelical missionaries under the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. After WLA died in 1944, GFA taught at Woodstock School and the Prentiss Girls' School in Etah.

did.unittitle: Diary: entitled "Daily Doings of Allisons 1920-1923 Vol I" - handwritten entries in bound ledger book provide detailed information regarding activities
Diary: "1924-1941 Vol. II": handwritten entries in bound notebook.

Circular letters and reports, primarily written by Grace Allison, from Etawah, Gwalior, Landour, Mainpuri, incl. re. educational and evangelical work, Sunday School work, social events, Woodstock School for missionary children, distribution of tracts and Gospel portions; biographical sketches of GFA
Alter, Martha Payne

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Martha Payne Alter (1890-1951) was a missionary to India from 1916 to 1951, serving under the United Presbyterian Church of North America. She was the mother of James Payne Alter, whose papers are held in YDSL Record Group No. 84. This collection contains the originals of letters that were published in Letters from India to America 1916-1951 by Martha Payne Alter, edited by Ellen and Bob Alter. An index to the letters is contained in the first folder.

Archer, John Clark

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Archer was born in 1881. Education: 1905 - B.A., Hiram College;1914 - B.D. and M.A., Yale; 1922 - Ph.D., Yale; Employment: 1915-1916 - Lecturer on Missions, Yale; 1916-1924 - Assistant Professor, Yale;1924-1927 - Associate Professor, Yale; 1927-1932 - Professor of Missions and Comparative Religion; 1932-1950 - Hoober Professor of Comparative Religion; 1950 - Professor Emeritus; 1932-1935 - Curator of Collection on Comparative Religion; He died 1957 Jul 7.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: (1920, 1930-1968, n.d.), arranged chronologically. Early correspondence with Luther Weigle and Andrew Keogh relates to courses offered by Archer and the Day Missions Library. Includes a few letters to Archer's wife after his death. Letters deal with Archer's writings and the 25th reunion of his Divinity School class of 1914, as well as the ambassadorship of Chester Bowles in India: correspondence with Jawaharlal Nehru and Indian diplomats. (5 folders)
Writings: Articles and Papers (1922-1954), arranged alphabetically by title (There is also a bound volume of articles by Archer in the library's restricted circulation collection)
Writings: Book Reviews (1938-1946). List of additional reviews included (1 folder)
Notes (n.d.) (1 folder)
Bibliographies; 2 parish programs of missionary education (1920, 1922) (1 folder)
Printed Material: Primarily newspaper clippings (1945-1960) (2 folders)
Memorabilia: Indian flags and hat
Biographical documentation: Memorial service for JCA, 1958 (1 folder)
Photographs and postcards: Mostly of Asia, unidentified (1 folder)

bioghist.p: James Hope Arthur was an American Baptist missionary in Japan 1873 to 1877. See biographical information in first folder.

Austin, Ralph V.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Austin (1895-1962) graduated from Yale Divinity School in 1924 after serving in the U.S. Army during WWI and attending Butler College. He served primarily Congregational churches in Connecticut, Indiana, and Wisconsin. This collection documents his ministry and involvement in social issues such as desegregation and migrant workers.

did.unittitle: Letters written to family members while in military service during World War I.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Austin joined the U.S. Army in July 1917 and sailed for France in December with the Second Division, serving in field hospitals in France, in Germany as part of the occupying forces, and in the United Kingdom. He was discharged in 1919.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 1 contains notes that are selected excerpts from WWI letters and diary.

did.unittitle: Diary / journal entries describing experiences in military training in U.S. and service in France and Germany; copy of Honorable Discharge from the U.S. Army, 1919 October 13
Documentation of four months study in London under auspices of American Army Educational Commission
Postcards and photographs, pamphlet on The Second Division, collected poems from period of World War I service
Documentation primarily from period serving at Winchester Center, Connecticut and attending Yale Divinity School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These folders include the contents of a file box that was divided alphabetically and contained letters and other documents. A few documents date from after Vernon moved back to Indiana from Connecticut.

did.unittitle: Documentation from period serving at Indianapolis, IN

did.unittitle: Documentation from period serving at Rhinelander, Wisconsin

Ayi, Francois

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ayi is a member of the royal family of Togo and was crowned king in 1994, though some question the legitimacy of his position. In 1997 Ayi founded the Royal Green Cross, an international youth volunteer program.

did.unittitle: Documentation regarding Ayi and the Royal Green Cross organization

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1749 - Born in Franklin, CT; 1769 - Graduated from Yale College; 1773 - Began service as postor of Congregational Church in Somers, CT; 1803 - Died

Backus, Simon (1701-1745)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1701 - Born in Norwich, CT, son of Joseph and Elizabeth (Huntington) Backus; 1724 - Graduated from Yale College; 1727 - Ordained, served Newington parish in Wethersfield, CT; 1729 - Married to Eunice Edwards, sister of Jonathan Edwards; 1737/38 - Son Simon born; 1745 - Sent by colony authorities to Louisburg, Cape Breton as chaplain to the 350 Connecticut troops stationed there to prevent a recapture of the post by the French. Was taken ill and died there.

did.unittitle: 22 manuscript sermons delivered by Backus in various Connecticut churches. Organized chronologically by earliest date noted on the sermon, 1724-1739 (3 folders)
Account record (1735-1736); goods and services received, with prices marked. (1 folder)
Letter written in by grandson, which includes biographical information regarding Simon Backus and his son Simon
Backus, Simon (1737/38-1823)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1737/38 - Born in Newington parish, Wethersfield, CT, son of Simon and Eunice (Edwards) Backus; 1759 - Graduated from Yale College; 1762 - Ordained as first pastor of a Congregational church just gathered in the southern part of Hadley, MA, now Granby, CT.; 1784 - Moved to Hanover, NH, and filled vacant pulpits in that vicinity; 1790 - Returned to CT, installed at Congregational Church in North Bristol, now North Madison; 1801 - Dismissed from his post after becoming involved in serious difficulties with the people of his parish. Lived in area for another 15 years, becoming increasingly impoverish. Later lived with his son in Bridgeport.; 1823 - Died in Stratford, CT

did.unittitle: 136 manuscript sermons organized chronologically by earliest date noted on the sermon (1760-1808)
42 undated manuscript sermons
Sermon fragments (8 folders)

Banninga, John J.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Banninga (1875-1963) graduated from Hope College in 1898 andWestern Theological Seminary in 1901. John and his wife, Sophia Maria "Mary" Damson left for India in 1901 and served there for forty-two years. In 1917, John became the principal of the Union Theological Seminary at Pasumalai in South India, a position he would hold for 25 years.

did.unittitle: Newspaper clipping re. return of Banningas to Michigan ca. 1906; printed circular letters describing Banningas' work in Pasumalai
Barone, Alfred D.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: A native of Italy, Rev. Dr. Alfred D. Barone converted to Protestantism and established Protestant missions throughout Italy under the auspices of the Home Mission Society of London. He came to the U.S. in 1899 and preached in CT and MA. In 1910 he established his own missionary and educational work under the name of the Alpha and Omega Assembly, based in New Haven, CT and Brooklyn NY.

did.unittitle: Handwritten ms. by ADB, "The Requisites necessary for the ministry's candidate examination"; photos of ADB and his wife, Rosina; NY Times obituary of ADB; leaflets and newsletters from the Alpha and Omega Assembly
Beardslee, Alvord

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Beardslee received a B.D. from Yale Divinity School in 1953 and an S.T.M. in 1955. He served as a Professor of Religion at Hollins College, VA and as Congregational minister in the United Church of Christ, Salisbury. He was a Research Fellow at YDS in 1981-1982 and 1989-1990. He served on the Alumnal Board of YDS and was a Trustee of the Foundation for the Preservation of Sterling Divinity Quadrangle. These personal papers of Beardslee complement documentation regarding YDS and the Save the Quad movement in Record Group No. 53, YDS Memorabilia.

did.unittitle: Foundation for the Preservation of Sterling Divinity Quadrangle documentation: meeting notes, administrative statements, campaign updates, Save the Quad publications
Foundation for the Preservation of Sterling Divinity Quadrangle documentation: applications/scholarship, letters

Beebe, David Lewis

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1763 - Born in Trumbull, CT; 1785 - Graduated from Yale College; 1791 - Ordained and served as pastor of the Congregational Church in Woodbridge, CT; 1800 - Left position in Woodbridge because of ill health; 1803 - Died in Catskill, NY, where he had entered into business.

did.unittitle: 259 manuscript sermons delivered in various Connecticut churches, most often in Woodbridge, CT. The sermons date from 1787 to 1798 and are arranged chronologically. One folder of undated, fragmentary, and attributed sermons follows the chronologically arranged sermons

did.unittitle: 60 manuscript sermons dating from 1753 to 1778. One folder of undated, fragmentary, and attributed sermons follows the chronologically arranged sermons

Also preached through Connecticut for part of the year; 1750 - Published True Religion Delineated ; 1758 - Published The Wisdom of God in the Permission of Sin ; 1790 - Died.

Bentley, Edward Warner

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1826 - Born in Tyringham, MA; 1850 - Graduated from Yale College; 1854 - B. D. from Hartford Theological Seminary; 1854-1881 - Pastor in Ellenville, NY; 1887 - Died in Canton Center, CT.

did.unittitle: Bound volume of holograph notes taken by Bentley on sermons delivered primarily in the chapels of Yale College and Hartford Theological Seminary during the years 1845 to 1853. Sermons were delivered by Noah Porter, Lyman Beecher, Walter Clark, President Hitchcock, and others.
Bergmann, H. F. W.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1899 Nov 11 - Born; Education included 6 years at seminary in Neuendettelsau; one year at University at Hamburg studying linguistics and languages of New Guinea and tropical medicine; 1926 - Arrived in New Guinea to begin mission work.

did.unittitle: Ten volumes of Bergmann's autobiographical work "Vierzig Jahre in Neuguinea" in typed manuscript form, in German. These volumes describe Bergmann's experiences in New Guinea from 1928 to 1968. He began the work in 1972 for use by his children and other relatives. It was not intended for publication. Donated by H. F. W. Bergmann of Harrisville, Australia.
Bilheimer, Robert

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bilheimer graduated from Yale Divinity School in 1945. He helped to organize the first meeting of the World Council of Churches in 1948 and served as a WCC associate general secretary. From 1963 he was senior minister of Central Presbyterian Church in Rochester, NY, returning to ecumenical work in 1966 as director of the international affairs program of the National Council of Churches. He was executive director of the Institute for Ecumenical and Cultural Research in Collegeville, MN before retiring in 1984.

did.unittitle: Paper written for Prof. H. Richard Niebuhr at YDS: "Paul The Transformation of the Twice-Born"

Notes and documents re. Cottesloe Consultation sponsored jointly by the World Council of Churches and its member churches in South Africa, which Bilheimer organized with Beyers Naud, an Afrikaner cleric from the Dutch Reformed Church, went on to become a leader of the white resistance to apartheid. Copy of letter from Bilheimer to Nelson Mandela upon his election as president
Two bound volumes of sermons and addresses from Bilheimer's time at Central Presbyterian Church, Rochester, NY
Compilation of letters received on the occasion of Bilheimer's retirement as Director of Ecumenical Institute, St. John's University, Collegeville, MN
Diary notes of RB
Annotated copy of A Diary of Private Prayer by John Baillie
Newspaper clippings documenting Bilheimer's trips to South Africa in the early 1960s to survey the situation there on behalf of the World Council of Churches
Articles by Bilheimer: "Ethical Problems of Economic Aid and Technical Assistance", "A Message in South Africa", "Let American Ecumenism be Ecumenical"

did.unittitle: Two typed letters from Bisbee to Brotherhood Bible Class of Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church in Minnesota regarding support for an Indian evangelist, Daud Kuber, with photo of Kuber and his wife
Blair, J. Andrew

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Blair was a printer who served under Dr. David Livingstone and the Universities' Mission to Central Africa, sailing from Britain in April 1861.

did.unittitle: Handwritten journal describes Blair's travel to and within Africa and efforts of the Universities' Mission to Africa to establish work in what is now Malawi. Typed excerpts and a summary of the narrative are included with the bound volume.
Bollier, John A.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bollier (1927-2010) received a B.A. from University of Michigan and M.Div. from Princeton Theological Seminary and served Presbyterian parishes in Pennsylvania and California from 1952 to 1970. In 1970 he received his library degree from UCLA and from 1973 to 1991 served as Public Service Librarian, and later Assistant Divinity Librarian, at the Yale Divinity Library, with terms as acting Divinity Librarian. Bollier was the author of The Literature of Theology : a Guide for Students and Pastors (1979). After retirement, he served as director of development for the American Theological Library Association.

did.unittitle: Biographical sketches and tributes, CV

Writings, sermons, lectures: including The Call to Personal Faithfulness. (Yale Divinity School Advent Preaching Series, December, 1981), tribute to Brevard Childs, "Bibliographic Lecture: Resources in Church History"
Writings, sermons, lectures: including "Knowledge of a Second Kind" in Reflections, 85/1, "Future Trends in Access to Archival and Library Resources"
Compilation of handouts documenting work as Public Services Librarian and Assistant Divinity Library, Yale Divinity Library
Materials related to "The Literature of Theology" Yale Divinity School bibliography course
Reports and correspondence related to Bollier's work with the American Theological Library Association

Bound notebook in which classmates of Bond wrote at the time of graduation from Bowdoin College (1835-1837)
Borden, William Whiting

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical

Yale College; founded the Yale Hope Mission; 1909-1912 - Princeton Theological Seminary; 1910 - Delegate to the Rochester Student Volunteer Convention and to the World Missionary Conference in Edinburgh; 1912 - Traveling Secretary for the Student Volunteer Movement; ordained at the Moody Church in Chicago; traveled to Egypt to study Islam and Arabic in preparation for work among the Moslems in China; 1913 - Died in Cairo.

Boyd, Corabel Tarr

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Boyd was an American woman touring mission schools throughout Japan, China, Indonesia, and Southern Asia.

did.unittitle: Bound volume of mimeographed letters titled "Around the World 1929-1930 Letters by Corabel Tarr Boyd."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The front of the volume has printed in gilt "Mr. and Mrs. C.C. Parlin" - the couple to whom the collection of letters was presented. This volume contains 28 mimeographed letters totaling 183 pages. Substantive letters describe Boyd's travels and visits to mission institutions.

did.unittitle: Boyd, Lena Agnes

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: American Presbyterian missionary to India, 1912-1948. Worked with Punjab Mission in Saharanpur, Hoshiarpur, Kasur, Jagraon in educational and zenana work.

did.unittitle: "Life Story of Lena Agnes Boyd, an American Presbyterian Missionary from Santa Anna, Texas to India (1883-1972) - a tribute by Amos Boyd
Brainerd, David

Brodie, Thomas L.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical

Taught: Regional Seminary of the Antilles, Trinidad, WI, 1968-1972, Regional Seminary, Boynton Beach, Florida, 1976-1980, Aquinas Institute, St Louis, MO, 1984-1991,Cedara Scholasticate and Univ. of Natal, Pietermaritzburg, S. Africa, 1992-1995. Moderator, Dominican Biblical Institute, Limerick, Ireland, 2000-.

Burke, Harry Taylor

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born November 13, 1909 in Bowling Green, Kentucky. Ordained as Episcopal priest in 1934 and appointed to educational work in the Philippines 1935-1945. Headmaster of St. Albans School, Zamboanga. Captured by Japanese army in May, 1942. Interned at Camp Holmes 1942-1944. Moved to Los Banos Internment Camp in 1944. Released February 1945. Returned to the U.S. and served various schools but returned to the Philippines regularly and provided support for students.

Cannon, Ralph A.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ralph Alston Cannon was born in 1929 and raised in Spartanburg, SC. He received a B.A. from Wofford College and graduated fromYale Divinity School in 1953. Cannon served as a minister of the Methodist Church in eleven congregations in South Carolina from 1953 to until his retirement in 1994.

did.unittitle: Portraits, biographical material; Sermons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The content of Cannon's sermons includes Biblical interpretation, doctrinal expositions, pastoral counsel, and "culture-relevant" messages about trends and pressures of the second half of the twentieth century in the American South. The sermons in this collection were written after they were preached. The sermon was taped during delivery, transcribed, edited and re-typed.

Corey, Clara Watts Long

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1868 Jul - Born at Tenant's Harbor, Maine. Attended public schools through age 17. Also attended Cobwin Classical Institute, Waterford, Maine for one and a half years and Newton Theological Seminary for one year; 1894 - Married the Rev. Hebron Young Corey. H.Y. Corey was born in 1862 in New Brunswick. Taught for 12 years following 1 year of Normal School. Attended Acadia College. Started Student Volunteer Band at Acadia in 1890. Attended Newton Theological Seminary 1891 - 1894; 1894-1924 - Missionaries to India under the Maritime Baptists of Canada (1894-1912) and Canadian Baptist Foreign Mission (1912-1924). Lived in Telugu area, primarily in Vizianagram Cant and Bimlipatam. H.Y. Corey served as an evangelist and as principal of a high school. Children: Cedric, Albert, Charles, Elizabeth.

did.unittitle: Approximately 150 letters (dating 1894-1900, 1910-1922, 1929) primarily from Clara in India to her mother in the United States. These letters are typed transcripts from the originals deposited at McMaster University. The letters deal primarily with the children and routine affairs of life for a missionary wife in India. Donor: Mrs. Elizabeth Jacks, Middlebury, CT

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Laura Elizabeth Corrie (1818-1908) was born in India, the daughter of Daniel Corrie, who was the first Anglican Bishop of Madras and later President of the Church Missionary Society. Laura Corrie married George Bird in South Africa in 1835 and had several children.

did.unittitle: A handwritten common place book compiled primarily in India (Calcutta in 1832, Madras in 1836 and 1837) and in South Africa (Cape Town in 1835).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The volume is attributed to Laura Corrie but not signed by her. Entries include excerpts from works related to missionary work in India, biographies of queens of England, poems and articles relating to the death of Daniel Corrie (1777-1837, Bishop of Madras.

Dirks, J. Edward

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1940 - B.A., Dubuque; 1943 - B.D., YDS; 1947 - Ph.D., Columbia; 1955-1958 - Associate Professor Religion in Higher Education, Yale Divinity School; 1958-1967 - Stephen Merrell Clement Professor of Christian Methods, YDS; 1967-1968 - Research Consultant, YDS.

did.unittitle: Addresses, Lectures, and Papers: Writings related to religion in higher education. Sample titles: "The Religious Dimension in Education", "The Community of Faith and the Community of Learning", and "A Theology of the Campus Christian Ministry" given at the Danforth Conference for Campus Christian Workers. Dirks' licensure and ordination lecture, "Justification by Faith", is included.

Yale Divinity School: Danforth Program: The Danforth Study of Campus Ministries, sponsored by the Danforth Foundation beginning in 1963, was directed by Kenneth Underwood, a YDS colleague of Dirks. The project documented the state of religious awareness and commitment on American university and college campuses.

Travel Diary: Documents Dirks' travels from February through June of 1957, in India, Asia, and the Middle East. Entries are primarily reflections on the various discussions Dirks had with professors, students, administrators, and church leaders concerning universities and higher education in general within these countries.

Shorter Publications: A variety of different theological publications containing articles written by and about Dirks. Sample titles: "Commemoration Day Address: 1964" and "The Pursuit of Learning to the Glory of God" in the Wesleyan Studies in Religion .
Sermons written by Dirks. Many of these sermons appear to be given within academic setting. Several were given at Yale Divinity School
One letter between the Office of the Dean at Yale Divinity School and Dirks

Longer Publications: Introductions, chapters, and drafts of books written by Dirks. Sample titles: "The Contemporary University World: Freedom and Responsibility in the Higher Learning of Today", "Impressions of Christian Colleges in Asia", and "The Christian Community at Study: (chapter I) A Theology of Knowledge for the Christian Educational Community".

Eddy family

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Washington Eddy (1811-1897) was an inventor of printer's ink. He and his wife, had communications with Presbyterian missionaries in Siam (Thailand) Mary Mattoon (wife of Stephen Mattoon) and Samuel R. and Henrietta House. The Houses were neighbors of the Eddys in upstate New York. Eddy also received letters and gifts from Chau Fa Mongkut, Crown Prince of Siam, who later became King and was popularized in the book "Anna and the King of Siam."

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Nathaniel Eells of Scituate, MA, was born in 1677, graduated from Harvard in 1699, and died in 1750. His sons included Samuel Eells (b. 1706 ), Nathaniel (b. 1711; pastor of the Congregational Church in Stonington, CT), and Edward (b. 1713; pastor of the Congregational Church in Middletown, CT ). James Eells, son of Edward, was born 1742/43 and licensed to preach in Glastonbury, CT in 1769; Earnest E. Eells, a later descendant, was a chaplain in the U.S. Navy.

Elliott, Arthur James

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: "Dad" A.J.Elliott (1875-1952) served the YMCA Student Division from 1907 to 1951. During the last sixteen years he was executive secretary of Christian evangelism among youth and led the student conferences held at Lake Geneva. Elliott traveled to Japan, China, and the Philippines in 1925 on behalf of the Student YMCA. In 1935 he was sent on a similar mission around the world. For additional biographical information see pamphlet Touchdowns for the Lord in the library's cataloged collection. See additional A.J. Elliott correspondence in Record Group No. 58, YMCA Student Division Archives.

did.unittitle: Obituary, photograph of A.J. Elliott.

8 mm. films taken during Elliott's travels. The films include views of the countries visited, Elliott and his wife Otillia, etc: 1) China: scenes of harbor, boats, streets, countryside, children, temple; 2) Japan: boats, people, pagoda, dancers, rickshaw, countryside, Japanese home; 3) Germany and Switzerland: railroad stations, Olympic Stadium in Berlin, parade of athletes, towns, League of Nations building; 4) Italy: Venice, lacemakers, streets, Rome, etc.; 5) Jerusalem and Egypt: pyramids, desert, camel riding, Wailing Wall, holy sites; 6-8) Russia / Soviet Union: school, stadium, folkdances, workers, military, parade, Stalin, Metro subway system, buildings, shrines, statues,Youth camp, harvesting; 9) Norway: scenes at sea, harbor, dancers, fjords, countryside; 10) In U.S.?: people in snow, airplane taking off, gardens

8 mm. films taken during Elliott's travels. The films include views of the countries visited, Elliott and his wife Otillia, etc: 1-2) India: tea at Maharah, school, lepers, Delhi, Agra, wealthy Indian family, Hindu temple, street scenes, Lahore; 3) Grand Canyon; 4) Yellowstone

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of letters written to Gould by various individuals, largely clergymen and missionaries, indicating whether they plan to attend the ABCFM annual meeting and whether they need accommodations. While many of the letters are short and factual, some provide background information about the types of individuals attending the meeting and the arrangements made for the meeting.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Graduating from Yale Divinity School in 1946, Arthur served churches in Chester and Wilton, CT prior to joining the staff of the CT UCC Conference staff, where he principally worked on housing and other social justice issues. Seeking greater visibility for the church's social action work among corporations and government, he created the New Samaritan Corporation in 1971. New Samaritan and its affiliated management companies grew to become Connecticut's largest nonprofit manager of housing for the aging and families.

Hill, George Gardner

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1919 -Born in Indiana, Pennsylvania; 1940 -Graduated from Indiana University of Pennsylvania; 1942-1946 -Served in U.S. Army; 1946-1953 -Employed by Hagan Ice Cream Co., Uniontown, Pennsylvania; 1957 -B.D., Yale Divinity School; 1953-1984 -Served Methodist churches in Connecticut and New York, except for; 1961-1963 in Tampa, Florida, and the year following at the Church Center at the United Nations; 1984-1988 -During his retirement years in New Haven, Hill published "The Hill Newsletter" and was involved with numerous organizations devoted to peace, spirituality and social issues. 1988 -Died.

did.unittitle: A series of newsletters prepared by Hill from 1960 to 1988. These newsletters were distributed in the churches served by Hill and/or sent by mail to a network of individuals who shared his concerns. Newsletters in this collection include: "Interpretation" 1960 Apr - 1961 Apr (18 issues); "The Contender" 1960 Sep - 1965 Mar, 1969 Jan (14 issues); "Church and World" 1964 Oct - 1984 Jun (146 issues); "The Hill Newsletter" 1984 Sep - 1988 Feb (43 issues); "The Hill Newsletter", which was issued jointly by Hill and his wife, Elizabeth Keeney Hill, has been compiled and indexed in a looseleaf notebook. The following description of "The Hill Newsletter" is taken from the introduction to the compilation: "(The Hill Newsletter) was distributed nationally and served as a major networking mechanism for peace advocates. It was also devoted to social issues, politics, national and international affairs, culture, religion, spirituality, and church integrity. It represents a candid, honest effort to transcend institutionalism and hypocrisy in American life, and to apply the principles of Jesus directly to current affairs. As such, it represents a unique commentary on American religious, political, and social life over the period from 1957 to 1988." Donors: Elizabeth K. Hill, James W. Hill.

Hovey, Gail

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Hovey was among the founders of the "Zambia Group," a small community of persons with a common history in the National Student Christian Federation/University Christian Movement who first met in Zambia in 1967. Most of the participants were involved in the Frontier Internship in Mission program and other programs initiated by Margaret Flory. The "Zambia Group" remained a community for some thirty years, centered on with a focus on concern for southern Africa. At annual meetings they focused on strategies for change in southern Africa and their relationships to those strategies. They sought one another's counsel about vocational, relational and resource decisions, pooling money to support activities both in the U.S. and in Africa for the liberation of southern Africa.

did.unittitle: Zambia Group files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Zambia Group files include minutes of annual meetings and financial records, including letters of acknowledgement from organizations supported by the group, such as the American Committee on Africa and SWAPO. There is extensive correspondence between members, both quarterly group letters and individual letters to the keeper of these files, Gail (Morlan) Hovey. See the first folder for additional information about the group. Documentation of the activities of group members complements other collections at YDSL,including the Washington Office on Africa archives and Episcopal Churchpeople for Southern Africa archives. The files also provide an interesting snapshot of life issues for a group of educated liberal Christian activists and educators in the second half of the 20th century.

Large, Dwight Sherer

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1911 Jul 31 Born in Tekonsha, MI to Rev. Samuel W. Large and Neve B. Large; - B.A., Albion College; 1936 - Graduated from Yale Divinity School; additional graduate work at Union Theological Seminary; 1936-1952 - Served various Methodist churches in Michigan, including Clarkston, Port Huron, Kalamazoo, and Ann Arbor; 1949 - Leave of absence (from Kalamazoo) to work with American Friends Service Committee, under the UN, serving Arab refugees on the Gaza Strip; 1953-1960 - Served First Methodist Church, Germantown (Philadelphia), PA; began the "What Then Are We To Do?" sheets; 1961-1971 - Returned to Michigan, serving Lansing Central and Detroit Central; 1971 - Retired from parish ministry; 1971-1978 - Implemented Amnesty Information and Action Center, in Ann Arbor; worked with the Michigan Christian Advocate; taught Crisis Counseling at Bangor Theological Seminary; volunteered with the Inter-religious Service Board for Conscientious Objection, in Washington, DC; 1978 - Relocated to Adelaide, Australia to be near son and his family; continued to volunteer, most significantly with the Executive Committee of UNAA; 1982 Sep 18 - Died.

did.unittitle: Original copies of "What Then Are We To Do?" sheets (1953 Sep 20 - 1971 May 30, 1978 Jun 18). (1 of 2 boxes)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These sheets were developed by Dwight Large during his parish ministry for each service and were distributed after worship as people went home. They were intended to supplement the Sunday worship service and to extend the 'church experience' throughout the week. Each sheet contains a brief summary of the sermon (50-60 words), Bible verses for each weekday, additional readings related to the sermon theme, and suggested activities to reinforce Christian awareness and growth. An index sermons (1967-1971) follows the "What Then Are We To Do?" sheets. Material donated by Mrs. Frances Large.

Lawson, Harvey Merrill

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lawson (1868-1948) was born in Union, Connecticut, graduated from Yale University Sheffield Scientific School in 1890, and Yale Divinity School in 1893. He was appointed as a missionary of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions and, with his wife Dedi Sarah Baldwin Lawson, arrived in India in 1893 to serve under the Maratha Mission. After suffering ill health, the Lawsons returned to the United States in 1897 and Lawson served as a minister in Union, Connecticut.

bioghist.p: 1888 - Born in Atlanta, MO; 1913 - B.A., Cotner College, Nebraska; 1913 - Ordained in Bethany, Nebraska (Disciples of Christ);1916 - B.D., Yale Divinity School; 1916, 1922 - Graduate work at University of Chicago; received D.D. from Univ. of Chicago; 1916-1917 - Professor of Sacred Literature, Eureka College; 1917-1919 - Chaplain of 333rd Heavy Field Artillery regiment, a.k.a. Mattoon, Stephen

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Mattoon was born May 5, 1816 in Champion, New York. In 1842, he graduated from Union College and from Princeton Theological Seminary in 1846. He was ordained as an evangelist on February 11, 1846 by the Presbytery of Troy. Dr. Mattoon was a missionary in Siam, Bangkok (Thailand) for 20 years. As a missionary he was as an interpreter to the King of Siam and organized the first Presbyterian Church of Siam. While in Cambodia, he started The Boys' School in Bangkok and translated the New Testament into Siamese. From 1870 to 1886, Dr. Stephen Mattoon served as first President of Johnson C. Smith University in North Carolina.

Morris, Thomas

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1792 Jan 18 - Born in England; 1816 Dec 15 - Ordained deacon of Cathedral Church of Norwich; 1818 Dec 20 - Ordained priest of Gloucester - Served as Perpetual Curate of Redcliff, Bedminster and Abbot's Leigh; 1820 Feb 10 - Departed for India as missionary under the Church Missionary Society. While in India, Morris learned the "Hindustani" language and was involved in the religious and educational work of the CMS Calcutta Mission. He served as chaplain to the Bishop of Benares;1829 Jan 17 - Left Calcutta with wife and children, due to ill health; 1829 May 11 - Arrived in England. Served churches in Twyford, Ruscombe and Hurst.

did.unittitle: Journal volume 1: - A diary/memoranda book containing sketchy account of daily activities in England as well as quotations and notes
Journal volume 2: diary/journal provides brief descriptions of daily activities in Calcutta and Benares, reports on travels to other towns and villages, commentary on the state of India
Journal volume 3: - Continuation of diary/journal

Journal volume 4: - Book containing thirteen letters or narrative sketches written by Morris during the period 1820 to 1824. The letters are addressed to "Rev. and dear Sir" or "Dear friend." Letters from Madeira, Cape Town, Ceylon, and Madras were written on Morris' voyage to Calcutta (1820 Mar-Jul). Eight letters/sketches describe Morris' work and travels in India. These writings provide valuable accounts of social customs, weather and the natural surroundings in India, as well as the perils of sea travel and the activities of early missionaries
Volume 5: - This volume received with the Morris papers dates from 1837 and describes travel in England and Scotland. It is written in a different hand than Volumes 1-4.
Five photographs, including three of Morris and two of his wife, Frances Hammett Morris. Some are photographs of paintings.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1759 Jun 11 - Born in Cheshire, CT; 1787 - Graduated from Yale College; after graduation studied theology with Benjamin Trumbull of North Haven; 1791 - Preached for six months in North Stonington, CT; 1792 - Called and ordained to serve the Congregational Church in Ware, Hampshire County, MA; during his ministry Moss experienced two periods of mental illness said to be related to a sunstroke suffered while a soldier in the Revolutionary War; 1809 - Died.

did.unittitle: Fifty-two ms. sermons filed by earliest date noted on the sermon. Locations where the sermons were preached and dates were recorded by Moss on the face of the sermon, the majority of them being preached in Ware, MA. Other towns such as Pelham, Stonington, Brookfield, Hardwick, New Braintree, Branford, and Cheshire are also noted as places where Moss preached the same sermons over a period of ten or fifteen years. The last date recorded is 1807. Material donated by K. D. Frankenstein, Salisbury, CT.

The Rev. Canon Dr. Richard T. Nolan served at Christ Church Cathedral, Hartford 1988-1994 and retired as Honorary Canon. Nolan was an associate in Continuing Education at Berkeley Divinity School at Yale in the 1980s.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Francis Owen (1802-1854), his wife S. Pennington Owen, and his sister Mary traveled to Natal, South Africa in 1836 to help with the work of the Church Missionary Society. Owen attempted to set up a mission station at Dingaan's Kraal, near Ulundi, among the Zulu people. King Dingaan used Owen as a secretary and go between in dealings with the Boers.

Hedges in 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rev. Townley was minister at the Presbyterian Church in Fresh Pond, a village of Huntington, Long Island, from 1837 to 1843. Letters to the church relate to his calling and to disturbances of worship by young people in the parish. The letter of the church trustees seems to relate to the same issue, but is undated.

Picron, Rene-Marie

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Picron (1906-1991) was a Salesian Roman Catholic missionary. He was a pastor at Kafubu, Belgian Congo from 1933 and later delegation superior for Congo. He was provincial in Belgium from 1952 to 1959, when North and South Belgium, Congo, Rwanda, and Burundi made up a single Salesian province. When the independent Central Africa Province was created in 1959 he returned to Africa and was engaged in various mission activities until his retirement in 1972.

Reddy, E.S.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Enuga Sreenivasulu Reddy was born on July 1, 1924, in Pallaprolu, India. From 1936 to 1965, Reddy was the principal secretary for the United Nations Special Committee Against Apartheid. He served as chief of the Section for African Questions from 1965 to 1976. Reddy was the assistant secretary-general of the United Nations from 1983 until his retirement in 1985. See Manuscript and Archives group MS 1499 for the bulk of the E.S. Reddy Papers. This collection, consisting of church-related printed material and correspondence that were transferred to the Divinity Library, complements YDSL RG 105, Washington Office on Africa, and RG 102 Episcopal Churchpeople for a Free Southern Africa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material consists of seven bound volumes prepared by Rice that contain typescript biographical sketches of missionaries and information regarding churches and missions of the Protestant Episcopal Church. Clippings, photographs, and chronological data are also included.

did.unittitle: Rigdon, Vernon Bruce

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Vernon Bruce Rigdon, born in 1936, is a pastor, social activist and theological educator affiliated with the Presbyterian Church USA. He graduated from Yale Divinity School (B.D. 1962) and Yale University (Ph.D. 1968). He has worked at McCormick Theologial Seminary, Grosse Pointe Farms (Michigan) Presbyterian Church, and Ecumenical Theological Seminary. He has been active in leadership and on several committees with the National Council of Churches (US-USSR Church Relations), World Council of Churches, and World Alliance of Reformed Churches.

Rogers, Miriam E.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Miriam Rogers was a native of Cleveland, Ohio who served as a missionary in India under the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions Marathi Mission. She first went to India from 1937 to 1949 and was involved in educational and child welfare work, stationed in Sholapur and Bombay. She contracted polio while in India and came back to the U.S. for rehabilitation. She returned to India in September, 1951 and served there under the ABCFM / United Church Board for World Ministries through the 1970s in Mahableshwar and Sholapur.

Schrading, Paul E.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Schrading received a B.D. from Yale Divinity School in 1958. He was involved in the student Christian movement both as a student and as a professional. As a student he held several offices in the National Student Committee of the YMCA from 1952-1955, and was Chairman of the USCC in 1956-57. As a professional, Schrading was the Associate General Secretary of University Christian Movement from 1966-1967, and became General Secretary of the UCM in 1968. A collection of his files can be found in the UCM records, Record Group 235..

Shepard, Henry B.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: After graduating from Yale College in 1949, Shepard taught at the American University in Cairo, and then was assistant director of the International Student House at the University of Goettingen in Germany in 1950 and 1951. He later attended Harvard Lae School and was an attorney in Boston. These records document Shepard's involvement with the Student Christian Movement while at Yale, with the World Student Christian Federation, and his ongoing financial support for the University Christian Movement in New England.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born in Scotland, 1841, Stevenson came to the America in 1863 by way of Canada. Following a period in Minnesota he served under the American Missionary Assoociation in Texas, teaching freed slaves, including as principal of Barnes Institute in Galveston. In 1872 he entered Yale Divinity School and received a B.D. in 1875. He served Congregational churches in Ellsworth, Connecticut (1875-1879), Shenandoah, Iowa (1880-1885) and Waterloo, Iowa (1896-1898). Later in life he lost his voice but continued to communicate via writing. He was the editor of the Woman's Standard , a suffragist newspaper, and wrote editorials for the Waterloo Courier . He died in 1912. For more detailed biographical information see a statement by his great granddaughter Flora Beach Burlingame in the first folder of the collection.

Summers, William

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Methodist missionary (1855-1888). One of a group of missionaries sent by Bishop William Taylor to Angola in 1885 to begin building a chain of missions across Africa. Summers set out from the mission station at Malange (now Malanje) in 1886 and made his way to Luluabourg (present-day Kananga, Democratic Republic of Congo). Summers spent his last days attempting to found a mission school among the Bashilange people of the southeastern Congo.

did.unittitle: Handwritten journal with typed transcript and summary by bookdealer. Almost daily entries describe Summers' journey from Luluabourg heading for village of the Bashilange chief Kasongo beginning in 1887; meetings with Africa leaders; military actions; etc. until his death in 1888.

Warren, Grace

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Warren graduated from the University of Sydney in 1954 and started her overseas missionary service in 1957 in Pusan, Korea. In 1959 she began work with the Leprosy Mission International in Hong Kong, learning techniques of reconstructive surgery. After ten years she made her base in central Thailand and traveled widely to run training programs in hospitals. She became an international authority in the care of neuropathic limbs, especially due to leprosy and diabetes, and in recontructive surgery.

did.unittitle: Two CDs contain PDF files of circular letters describing Warren's medical work, life, and travels spanning the years 1963 to 2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1904 Jun 27 - Born in Germany; Educated at the University of Wurzburg and Munich, Doctor of Law and Economics; Lawyer to large chemical concern in Germany; 1928 -Emigrated to the United States; continued to work in chemical business; Wrote articles on Servetus and the economic history of the 18th century; Wrote article on Sebastian Franck for The Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Macmillan Co.); 1984 Apr 21 -Died.

did.unittitle: One box of handwritten notes from Jacques Whitfield's research on Sebastian Franck and related topics. Whitfield was encouraged by his friend Roland Bainton to write a book about Sebastian Franck. Though this book was never completed, Whitfield did amass a great deal of information about Franck. His collected photocopies of books and dissertations by or about Franck have been added to the Library's cataloged collection. The notes in this collection are primarily from secondary sources, written in English or in German. Material donated by Ruth Whitfield.

did.unittitle: Personal correspondence of WFW. Letters were written mainly to Dwight Whitney Marsh, another missionary working for the Eastern Turkey Mission. The hand-written letters record impressions of his daily life, his difficulties in learning Arabic, the development of his children, the political climate of Eastern Turkey, as well as the details of mission business.
Sermon notes and a hand-written religious tract, entitled "The Evangelization of the World: The Duty of Every Christian."
Letters by family members, including 2 short letters by WFW's son, Talcott. Letters from what appears to be a native woman, Salome Sharabet, addressed to Dwight Whitney Marsh.
Map and index of Mardin Station; Williams' own architectural drafts for his house, the school, stables, and a seminary.

Wishard, Luther Deloraine

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1854 - Born in Danville, IN; ca. 1870 - Attended Indiana University; 1872 - Attended YMCA International Convention at Lowell, MA, while a student at Hanover College; 1875-1877 - Princeton University; 1877-1887 - As student secretary of the YMCA he established and enlarged the American intercollegiate movement; 1887-1899 - Foreign secretary of the International Committee of the YMCA; 1925 - Died.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: primarily letters written by Wishard to C. K. Ober
Printed material: includes article by Wishard, "The Young Men's Christian Association in India" and a supplement to the Morning Star, Jaffna, Ceylon (1890) regarding a YMCA convention
Woodger, Harriet Mabel

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harriet Mabel Armstrong Woodger was born in Ireland and served under the Church Missionary Society in West China from approximately 1935 until 1949. She then went to Kenya and worked in the tea business, including during the Mau Mau uprising.

did.unittitle: Typescript memoir "Pigtails: Autobiographical Sketches on Travels to China and Kenya and the life found there, 1932-1966"
Wooding, Ada E.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ada E. Wooding was a missionary in San Salvador, Congo, serving under the Baptist Missionary Society.

did.unittitle: Quarterly letter from Wooding addressed to "My dear Friends" describes mission work and native practices.
Woods, Leonard

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: 1774 Jun 19 -Born in Princeton, MA; 1796 -Graduated from Harvard; 1798 -Ordained minister at Newbury, MA; 1808-1846 -Professor of theology, Andover Seminary; 1854 -Died.

did.unittitle: Bound volume of notes on lectures given by Woods, 1837-1838. Volume also includes minimal notes on lectures by Professors Dwight, Emerson, and Stuart
Wuerffel, Mark and Sonja

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Missionaries serving in Papua New Guinea under Wycliffe Bible Translators.

did.unittitle: Newsletters
Yardley, Henry Albert

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Yardley (1834-1882) taught at Berkeley Divinity School, Middletown, Connecticut from 1863 to 1882.

did.unittitle: Bound volume of holograph notes taken by Henry T. Scudder on lectures of Prof. Henry A. Yardley (n.d.). Lectures on: Natural Theology, Christian Evidences
Zanisi, Angelo Saverio

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Zanisi worked as a missionary in North Malabar, India from 1951-1956. He moved to the Philippines in 1956, working at the Papal Embassy in Manilla for a year and then beginning a new Mission on the island of Samar in the town of Jipapad. He left the Philippines in 1983.

Zorn, Herbert M.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Zorn served with the Theological Education Fund (TEF) based in London from 1972 to 1975. He was coordinator of a study on the viability of theological education in the majority world, which was published as "Viability in Context"

did.unittitle: "Viability in context : a study of the financial viability of theological education in the Third World, seedbed or sheltered garden?"
Travel notes of Zorn during evaluation of theological education institutions in India, Indonesia, Philippines, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Korea, Africa, etc.: typescript and CD
Unidentified

250 page manuscript diary written by unidentified woman missionary, mostly in Kenya, where she was working for the African Inland Mission. Colleagues Charles and Florence Skoda are mentioned. She tells in detail of her daily work and teaching.
Approximately forty handwritten sermons, some dated but with no indication of author or locations preached; one printed funeral sermon, one pamphlet titled "Mount-Carmel, Feb. 1822"
